citations.narrative:
The primary enclosure housing ten young rabbits has two ceramic crocks for the rabbit pellets fed to the rabbits. These
crocks are large enough for the young rabbits to sit in while eating. There is rabbit feces mixed with the rabbit pellets and
the rabbit pellets underneath cake the bottom of the crock.
Food that is contaminated with feces is not wholesome or palatable and caking food has deteriorated to a point that it may
not be palatable or nutritious. Lack of a clean, nutritious and palatable food can lead to poor body condition and growth of
the young rabbits.
Food receptacles shall be accessible to all rabbits in a primary enclosure and shall be located so as to minimize
contamination by excreta. All food receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. If self
feeders are used for the feeding of dry feed, measures must be taken to prevent molding, deterioration or caking of the
feed.
To be corrected by October 9, 2024

The primary enclosure housing nine ducks does not have any water area for the ducks.
Lack of a water source can lead to poor feather quality, the inability to maintain an appropriate body temperature, and
does not allow for them to clean their eyes and nostrils.
Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area (e.g., ponds, waterfalls,
fountains, and other water features) and a dry area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area.
Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient surface area and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural
and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and
freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure. Dry areas must be of sufficient size to
allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to
escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure. Inadequate space may be indicated by evidence of
malnutrition, poor condition, debility, stress, or abnormal behavior patterns.
To be corrected by October 12, 2024

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
There is no plan for environmental enhancement for the 46 chickens and 9 ducks held by the facility.
Birds have complex needs which if unmet may cause stress, boredom, and the development of abnormal harmful
behaviors.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for
environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the
attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with currently accepted
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. This plan must be made
available to APHIS upon request.
Corrected at time of inspection
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and a family member.
